Speaker.P: He has a medical card.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: If their income is £90 or £100 they may be over the income eligibility limit of £85 but that will be reviewed in January anyway. I will check but that is the position. At this stage I am afraid I am not in a position to add anything to what has already been stated on the question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tunney Mr. Tunney
Speaker.P: A Cheann Comhairle——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: A question only, Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tunney Mr. Tunney
Speaker.P: There are particular circumstances in this case. If the seventies were not socialist, why could the eighties not be? Would the Minister not have the right himself? I am surprised that the Minister would say that he feels hidebound by decisions of other Ministers.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I will not permit another speech.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tunney Mr. Tunney
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not accept that in the case of a single man in a wheelchair who gets married to a girl who is working——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy is making another speech and that is not permissible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tunney Mr. Tunney
Speaker.P: ——surely it is not intended that he be subjected to the exclusion.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Energy the present position in relation to the number of small hydro-power units on stream, whose surplus electricity is being sold to the national power grid; and if he plans to encourage this trend by the introduction of economic incentives.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. Spring) Dick Spring
Speaker.P: At present there are 21 small privately owned hydro-electric power units connected to the national grid whose surplus capacity is bought by the ESB. During the year ended March 1984, a total of 6.5 million units generated by private hydro schemes was purchased by the ESB. No direct financial incentives are, at present, available from my Department for the development of hydro-power projects. In 1981, however, a competition was held for the design and development of small hydro schemes. This competition resulted in thirteen projects being grant-aided to the value of £98,800. Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Energy in view of the fact that work in other countries has shown that a considerable investment in Ireland of as much as £1,000 million in energy conservation would be more cost effective than investment in energy supply and distribution, would create jobs and would generate savings, the inducements and incentives provided by the Government to encourage energy conservation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. Spring) Dick Spring
Speaker.P: The allocation of funds to meet expenditure of the magnitude suggested by the Deputy on Energy conservation could not be considered either practicable or feasible. In any event, there is no evidence available to me to support the view that such investment would achieve the results claimed. Within the limits of resources available to my Department, an energy conservation programme is being carried out. The aim of the programme is to achieve cost effective savings with the greatest voluntary cooperation.

My Department offers the following free services carried out by the HRS: (i) four regional energy conservations officers; (ii) a public building advisory service; (iii) a steam plant audit service consisting of a test of steam traps, boilers and pipe insulation.

These services are aimed at the industrial, commercial and public sectors. In addition, fifteen booklets on different aspects of energy efficiency have been prepared for industry and grants of one-third the cost of fuel efficiency surveys are also available. An active forum for the exchange of information is the Energy Management Association, originally set up and funded by my Department and now semi-autonomous.

For the domestic sector, advice on energy conservation is available on telephone Numbers 01-376666 and 01-375107/8. Advice and encouragement are given by the NBST to those interested in participating in the EEC scheme of aid for energy projects with new technology or demonstrations value of ways of saving energy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kenny Mr. Kenny

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. Spring) Dick Spring
Speaker.P: Following on my request to the ESB last May to re-evaluate the cost of electricity supply to Inisturk Island, County Mayo, it has now been decided to extend supply to the island through a central generating system.

MainHeading.P: Before work on the project itself can commence, it will be necessary for the islanders to form a co-operative to administer the electricity supply on the island and a suitably qualified person who will operate the system will have to be appointed. The ESB have informed me that they are having discussions with the islanders in regard to formation of a co-operative at present. Commencement of initial work on the project itself (construction of a suitable building to house the generation equipment and transport of the plant and machinery to the island) will depend on seasonal factors and availability of equipment. The ESB estimate that, assuming early formation of a co-operative by the islanders, the initial work could commence in early summer of 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he intends to make financial assistance available to the 165,000 Saharoui refugees in South Algeria in response to a submission already made to his Department by a Polasario representative; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry)
Speaker.P: The request made to my Department on 26 November by a representative of Polasario for a specific sum in aid for Saharoui refugees is being considered. I should point out that the relief operation for the people in question is being handled by among others the UN High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR). This is one of the normal international channels through which the Government provide assistance for refugees. The Government make a substantial annual contribution to the UNHCR for its work in assisting refugees. In addition, at the International Conference on Assistance to Refugees in Africa held in Geneva in July this year the Government pledged IR£75,000 to UNHCR for its operations with refugees in Africa.

The human suffering arising from the conflict over the territory of Western Sahara is a matter of concern. It is to be hoped that a ceasefire can be brought about and that a referendum can then be held in which the people of Western Sahara could exercise their right to self-determination. The Government support efforts in this direction which have been made by the Organisation of African Unity. The Government hope that these efforts can be resumed despite the setback at the most recent OAU summit in Addis Ababa.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Merchant Shipping Industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. A. Doyle Mrs. A. Doyle
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications the Government's policy in relation to a future merchant shipping industry; if they realise that there is a necessity for a foreign-going service under that control; if they appreciate that the effect of the liquidation of Irish Shipping will be that there will be no qualified certificated foreign-going personnel and no trainees now that a new international regulation states that certs expire after five years ashore; if there is an EC requirement for a minimum foreign-going tonnage per member country and if so, what it is in relation to Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Communications (Mr. J. Mitchell) Jim Mitchell
Speaker.P: In the aftermath of the liquidation of Irish Shipping Limited my Department are carrying out a review of policy in relation to the Irish merchant shipping industry. I am not yet in a position to make a statement in the matter.

MainHeading.P: The International Convention of Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers, 1978 (STCW) was ratified by Ireland on 11 September last and will come into force for Ireland with effect from 11 December next. The provisions of the STCW Convention in relation to the continued proficiency and updating of knowledge of masters and deck and engineer officers are set out in Marine Notices Nos. 23 and 24 of 1984 which were issued by my Department. Briefly, a certificate of competency or service held by a master, deck officer or engineer officer will remain valid for sea-going service for a period of five years from entry into force of the Convention or from the date of issue of the certificate, if later, subject to the holder being medically fit for such service. Thereafter, the certificate will remain valid for sea-going service for a further five year period if the holder has served in his certificated capacity in sea-going ships of any flag for the last 12 months (which need not be continuous) during the preceding five years. Alternatively, satisfactory completion of an approved shore-based updating course or three months sea-going service of a specified kind may be sufficient to revalidate a certificate. The foregoing requirements, moreover, may be waived in certain circumstances e.g. if the holder of a certificate has served in certain employments which provide equivalent experience to sea service. Marine Notices 23 and 24 of 1984 set out the relevant details.
There is no EC requirement for a minimum foreign-going tonnage per member country.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: Disabled person's maintenance allowance is payable subject to a means test to certain persons who, due to a disability, are unable to undertake work suited to their age, experience and qualifications. I understand that a medical examination in this case indicated that the person in question is not disabled to this extent. An appeal against the decision was received by the South-Eastern Health Board on 30 November 1984. A final decision will be taken in the near future.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health in view of the increasing number of homeless children, if he plans to increase the number of foster families.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The number of children being placed by health boards with foster families has shown a significant increase in recent years. One of the main contributory factors has been the introduction by my Department of a new approach to the recruitment and training of foster parents. The new scheme, which is known as the “Parenting Plus Scheme” includes special training for social workers and foster parents and an educational programme for prospective foster parents. This more structured approach to recruitment has resulted in a greater awareness of fostering. I am confident that it will continue to assist boards to maintain and increase their pool of suitable foster parents.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the total capital cost incurred on Beaumont hospital to date; the monthly cost of debt service on this capital sum; the monthly cost of maintenance at the hospital; and, in the light of these figures, if he will take urgent steps to ensure that the enormous real cost each month to the taxpayer of this hospital remaining idle will be quickly brought to an end.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The total capital cost incurred on Beaumont hospital to date is £47.5 million. It is not possible to provide a monthly cost of debt service on this capital sum, since these costs form part of a large pool of funds borrowed at home and abroad at different rates of interest. The average monthly cost of maintenance, including staff salaries, is at the present time running at a cost of approximately £74,000.
Beaumont hospital is scheduled to open in July 1985 and the processes necessary to commission the hospital as scheduled are being actively pursued.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The remarks referred to were aimed primarily at the food processing industry and it is a matter for the industry itself to ensure that its quality control standards meet the requirements of the domestic and export markets. My Department's main concern in relation to quality control is to ensure that food products are sound and wholesome and are processed under hygienic conditions. It also enforces regulations on the grading and packing of certain products such as fresh fruit and vegetables, potatoes and eggs.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: In the National Economic Plan 1985-87 the Government have committed themselves to a fresh onslaught on bovine disease, particularly tuberculosis. To that end, the Government have set aside substantially increased funds for the eradication schemes over the next three years and have also detailed a series of measures with the express purpose of speeding up the eradication process.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Milk Processing Sector Investment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture given the view of Bord Bainne that the processing sector needs considerable investment this year to maintain plant and equipment in line with competitive activity, the measures he considers appropriate to encourage this investment; and furthermore, if he considers it timely to take steps, in view of the massive amounts of capital involved, to encourage co-operation between cooperatives, a move recently advocated by the Agricultural Institute to foster product diversification.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: There is of course, an ongoing need in the milk processing sector for investment in plant and equipment, and my Department and the State agencies concerned actively promote and encourage such investment. This matter is, however, primarily one for the dairy industry itself as indeed, is the issue of product diversification. I am aware that the industry has been examining how best to achieve increased product diversification and I would urge that it should avail itself fully of the grant aid which is available from the Industrial Development Authority. The high priority given by the Government to the development of the food industry and the strategy for the production of added value, consumer-type products are clearly indicated in the national economic plan Building on Reality, 1985-1987.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the measures he plans to take to encourage uptake of funds under the western package provisions for commonage division fencing and pasture improvements, which were aimed at 4,600 farmers dividing and fertilising 148,000 acres, and under which, out of a total of £16.8 million provided over ten years, to date a mere £45,512 has been paid in grants towards the completion of 39 schemes involving 70 farmers and 500 acres; in particular, if he agrees that it is disturbing that no application has been received from counties Cavan, Leitrim, Longford and Monaghan, while only three applications have been received from farmers in Roscommon; and if he agrees that it is a matter of urgency to take steps to promote the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: This scheme came into operation in 1981 and has been well publicised. To date, 5,816 hectares of commonage have been legally divided but the situation in regard to the carrying out of follow-up work — fencing, reclamation etc. — by the owners of the divided plots is not satisfactory. The potential for commonage division in the counties mentioned by the Deputy is less than in other parts of the west and a lower uptake is accordingly not surprising. The programme under which the western package operates is due for review next year in consultation with the EC Commission and opportunity will be taken to introduce any changes considered necessary to make the overall implementation of the package more effective.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he considers it a satisfactory position that Ireland produces only 5.7 per cent of the Community's sheepmeat, and if he will outline the present position and the likely results in relation to the measures designed to increase the flock of 1.6 million ewes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: As the Community is only 76 per cent self-sufficient in sheepmeat it is reasonable to anticipate some expansion in flock numbers and production, particularly in Ireland's case. In fact, between 1980 and 1984 the number of breeding ewes in Ireland has increased from 1.6 million to 1.8 million.

My Department encourage increased production in a variety of ways, including the greater use of more prolific ewes. In addition, expert advice is available from ACOT and AFT. However, efforts to expand production further will have only limited success unless producers observe the necessary market disciplines in relation to the disposal of lambs of the right quality at the right time.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Cork Garda Station.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wallace Mr. Wallace
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice when the full complement of gardaí will be assigned to the new Garda station in Gurranebraher, Cork; the total number of members that will be assigned there; the geographical area under the jurisdiction of the new station; and if an officer of superintendent rank will be assigned there.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The new Garda station at Gurranebraher serves the area formerly policed from Shandon station. I am informed by the Garda authorities that the current overall Garda strength at Gurranebraher is 36, all ranks, which represents a net increase of seven over the strength of the station party which transferred there from Shandon on 3 August 1984. The Garda authorities have no proposals at present to allocate additional manpower to Gurranebraher station but the matter will be kept under review.

The superintendent at McCurtain Street station has responsibility for the policing of the Cork City North Garda District, which includes the area served by Gurranebraher station, and any question of altering this arrangement will be a matter for consideration in the course of the current review of the organisation of the Garda Síochána in Cork city and surrounding areas.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Dea Mr. O'Dea
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the anomaly in the law relating to the family home whereby if the family home is in the joint names of both spouses, then, if one spouse deserts the other the general view within the legal profession is that the spouse who has deserted does not lose his-her rights over the family home for 12 years; if he agrees that this is unfair, particularly since, under existing legislation, a spouse who deserts another cannot object to the other spouse selling the family home after he-she has been deserted for two years; and if he will introduce legislation to rectify this anomaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Even accepting what is said in the first part of this question and I express no opinion on the view set out therein, I do not see that an anomaly arises. The question deals with two different types of rights in relation to property and different considerations would obviously apply in the regulation of them. Incidentally the Family Home Protection Act 1976 does not specify any period of desertion before a spouse's consent to sale of the family home will be dispensed with.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice when the necessary legislation in relation to the law of domicile will be introduced in the Dáil; and when the new Bill in relation to joint ownership of the family home will be introduced.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Work is proceeding on the preparation of legislation on both these matters and the legislation will be introduced as soon as possible. It is expected that the legislation on domicile will have to deal not only with that matter but also with the important related subject of the rules of recognition of foreign divorces.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will state in respect of Ministers and Ministers of State with State cars; (1) the cost of this transport in the year ending 1 December 1984 or nearest date; and (2) the estimated cost in the year ending 31 December 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): As indicated in reply to previous Questions, it is difficult to be precise about such costings, but, on the basis of a detailed analysis carried out early in 1983 and allowing for (a) subsequent increases in pay and allowances and car costs such as fuel etc. and (b) savings due to reduced usage and smaller cars, it is calculated that the cost for the year ended 1 December 1984 was, on average, £78,000 per user.

In relation to the year ending 31 December 1985, the cost would reflect changes in pay and allowances of drivers, in car costs and in the level of usage during that period. Accordingly, it is not possible to provide more than a tentative estimate which is that there may be an increase over the 1984 figure of the order of 5 per cent - 7 per cent.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will agree that her Department's policy of providing a quota of up to 10 per cent of all places in teacher training colleges, and also a number of places in colleges of home economics to people living in the Gaeltacht areas is no longer realistic and that it clearly discriminates against applicants from other areas; and if she will review this anomaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The practice of reserving up to 10 per cent of places in the colleges of education for qualified Gaeltacht candidates was introduced when the preparatory colleges were discontinued in 1967 and is maintained for the sake of the enrichment it provides to Irish language courses in colleges of education and to ensure an adequate supply of teachers whose first language is Irish for Gaeltacht schools and for national schools generally throughout the State. I am satisfied that there is a continuing need for this arrangement.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Wexford National School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware of the overcrowded and unfit condition of Bree national school, County Wexford; if she is aware that six teachers and six classes are housed in three classrooms, two prefabricated buildings and a hall three hundred yards distance from the school from which the children must walk to and fro in all kinds of weather and that sanitation facilities are way below standards; if she will, as a matter of urgency, sanction the building of the necessary accommodation immediately; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department have received a satisfactory sketch scheme for the extension proposed to Bree national school, County Wexford, whereby the school will be provided with a total of six classrooms and a general purposes area.

My Department are in communication with the school authorities regarding the local contribution towards the cost of the project and the production of evidence of good title to the parcel of land required by way of site extension. As soon as these matters have been resolved, my Department will sanction a grant for the proposed extension. The preparation of contract documents can then be put in hands. It is not possible at this stage to say when building work on the project may commence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Community Youth Work.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will give full details of all financial and other assistance available to organisations involved in community youth work.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: My Department support community youth work by making financial assistance available for voluntary youth organisations and groups to assist them provide educational and recreational programmes for young people. Total financial assistance allocated for this purpose to date in 1984 is £2,124,794.
This is broken down as follows:
Youth Service Grants to Headquarters Youth Organisations — £1,878,650;
Grants for In-Service Training of Full time Youth Workers — £26,456;
Grants for youth projects in disadvantaged areas — £148,000;
Miscellaneous — £18,325;

MainHeading.P: Cross-Border and British-Irish Exchange Schemes — £53,363.

My Department, also, through the youth employment scheme and AnCO's community youth training programme provide substantial assistance to community youth work. The new social employment scheme will also be specifically geared to assist community groups, youth clubs and other similar organisations. Of course, a number of other Government Departments also support the promotion and development of community youth work.
